final_poem:
The night comes down like a wet shawl,
drawing every color from the land.
The river goes gray as if it were swallowed
by some vast throat that does not demand.

Even the stars, those punctual singers,
tire by ten. The sky softens its frame
until the earth is just a softness
beneath a deepening of blue and black.

A dog barks once — three miles away or more —
and the quiet swallows it like breath.
The world does not wait for anything.
It simply dissolves into dark's thick skin.

There is a kind of peace in this.
Not the fake peace before dinner,
but the real settling, the full weight
of darkness holding everything still.

I keep the house warm with a low fire.
Outside, whatever happened, however often,
has finished. The trees stand patient,
each one breathing just above its bark.

This is the hour that doesn't ask anything of you.
You can sit on a porch swing or lie down
in tall grass and let the earth take shape
through your eyelids — dark, then darker,
black with a thin thread of moon
that even in absence keeps its name.
